componenttextpreview: It's everything we use in the agricultural complex.
componenttext: It's everything we use in the agricultural complex.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Given the competitive conditions, I guess, then as you look at pricing moving forward, do you feel comfortable being able to raise prices in the current economic environment, maybe especially now that milk prices are coming up might give you a little bit
componenttext: Given the competitive conditions, I guess, then as you look at pricing moving forward, do you feel comfortable being able to raise prices in the current economic environment, maybe especially now that milk prices are coming up might give you a little bit of room to increase prices on your non-milk portfolio?

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the dynamics in WhiteWave-Alpro are just very different. First of all, you have surging volumes there. So our volumes this year in that business will be up high-single digits to close to double digits in the business across the portfolio. And
componenttext: Yes. I think the dynamics in WhiteWave-Alpro are just very different. First of all, you have surging volumes there. So our volumes this year in that business will be up high-single digits to close to double digits in the business across the portfolio. And we have very strong share positions in almost all of those categories. And I think all of the people that we compete with in those spaces are going to be taking price. So we heard Sara Lee come out this morning saying, "Hey, we got lots of commodity inflation. We're going to be out there taking price." And they're just the last of a long line of folks who have said that. So that will be the -- we're going to have to take some price to maintain our profitably at WhiteWave-Alpro. And we believe in that segment of the industry, the dynamics are much more favorable to taking price than they are in liquid milk.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: You've had a number of senior-level management changes here over the last year or so. I'm just wondering, as you look forward, and your strategy, it seems very consistent, I think, with what you've been telling us. I'm just wondering, are you comfortable
componenttext: You've had a number of senior-level management changes here over the last year or so. I'm just wondering, as you look forward, and your strategy, it seems very consistent, I think, with what you've been telling us. I'm just wondering, are you comfortable with the current management team you have in place? And if there'd be any kind of rethink on your strategy, given some of this high-level turnover?

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Christine, we are absolutely committed to the strategy we're on. We believe it's not only the right strategy but, frankly, the only sensible long-term strategy for the category and for this business. We have a very, very sound team that we've built over t
componenttext: Christine, we are absolutely committed to the strategy we're on. We believe it's not only the right strategy but, frankly, the only sensible long-term strategy for the category and for this business. We have a very, very sound team that we've built over the last five years. You're seeing some natural evolution in the team as executives reach different parts of their career and, frankly, experience some natural fatigue of going through a very, very difficult environment here for the last three or four years. And I think it's a credit to the leadership of the business that we have built such a strong bench here that most of the evolution of our management team is happening internally. So these are not unexpected moves in a business of our size and scope and undergoing a wrenching transformation. And we've got a great stable of talent in the house to continue to drive forward on our strategy.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll next hear from David Palmer from UBS.
componenttext: We'll next hear from David Palmer from UBS.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Big picture question here, is the compressed margin environment, really, as you look at it, simply a result of one, two, three large-scale food retailers having a strategy to use private label as a loss leader or traffic driver? And/or is this also perhap
componenttext: Big picture question here, is the compressed margin environment, really, as you look at it, simply a result of one, two, three large-scale food retailers having a strategy to use private label as a loss leader or traffic driver? And/or is this also perhaps partly the result of more aggressive behavior from other dairies under new ownership, and we've seen some structure changes in terms of who you're competing with out there? Could you perhaps comment on that, and to the degree that other dairies had been more aggressive, is it becoming less clear to Dean that you guys have the low-cost advantage that we would think that you would have versus your competition? We'd love your thoughts.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: None of these things are totally black-and-white. How I would characterize it is that this ball got rolling down the hill with lots of energy as a result of changes in the retail environment. So a recession, consumers seeking value, retailers seeking to s
componenttext: None of these things are totally black-and-white. How I would characterize it is that this ball got rolling down the hill with lots of energy as a result of changes in the retail environment. So a recession, consumers seeking value, retailers seeking to show value to their customers with key value items. And as it often does, it starts with a few big retailers or a few new entrants, and we have some each of those in the grocery category, that gets things moving downhill. So when they get moving downhill, then there are collateral effects. And so as the retail price environment deteriorated, you get responses from the entire retail community, now trying to stay in value and match. And then you get price pressure back up the supply chain with retailers looking for help in funding this strategy. So in that environment, you get a bit of a churning of the pot in which the buying community, the retail community, is leveraging the excess capacity that exists, and it exists throughout everybody's network. And now manufacturers, back to Judy Hong's point, start focusing on the fact that they got fixed-cost infrastructure that they got to cover, and they compete to retain volume. So that's the basic dynamic. It started with the retail environment, and it's rippled back into the processor environment. We really don't see, even with these changes in ownership of other processors, we don't see people actively seeking to grow their share, right? People are trying to hold volume in their facilities, and then in declining category, ultimately that means growing share a little bit because there's less volume for everybody. So if you want to hold your volume, you got to take a little share. But we don't see people actively initiating lower pricing around the environment. It's more responsive. That’s not to say it doesn't happen at all. Again, it's not black and white, but these plants are in fixed geographies and they can serve fixed markets and customer bases and people maybe look a little farther afield from their plants, but I think the processing industry is in a very reactive mode right now.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And to answer your question on our cost position relative to the marketplace. We're better than we were three, four years ago, not as good as we need to be in order to have a sustainable cost advantage in the market. And that's the basis for all of Gregg'
componenttext: And to answer your question on our cost position relative to the marketplace. We're better than we were three, four years ago, not as good as we need to be in order to have a sustainable cost advantage in the market. And that's the basis for all of Gregg's comments earlier on attacking our supply chain, permanently removing structural cost and getting into a position that's very difficult for the competition to meet.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in the last couple of quarters, have you even passed what you said originally, made some additional cutting cost efforts? I mean, is there any numbers you can talk about in terms of how much bigger your targets are getting in terms of cost cutting?
componenttext: And in the last couple of quarters, have you even passed what you said originally, made some additional cutting cost efforts? I mean, is there any numbers you can talk about in terms of how much bigger your targets are getting in terms of cost cutting?

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we've said really clearly is, we're going to hit this $300 million in three years. And then for the next three to five years, we're going to put another $100 million per year on top of that. So we've been running at $100 million a year pace, and we'r
componenttext: What we've said really clearly is, we're going to hit this $300 million in three years. And then for the next three to five years, we're going to put another $100 million per year on top of that. So we've been running at $100 million a year pace, and we're going to keep that up for a total of six to eight years from the beginning of this process in 2009. So we're on path to hack a massive amount of cost out of this organization. And just as evidence of that, I think this is actually quite a remarkable number. In the first nine months of this year, we've taken net over 1,000 headcount out of our FDD-Morningstar business. That's a huge number, and we’ve got a lot of cost to take out of this business.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if you want to translate what that means, it means fewer facilities, fewer routes and fewer people in our organization as we go forward, right? That's the structural cost that has inherent inefficiency in it as we move to the supply chain that we're g
componenttext: And if you want to translate what that means, it means fewer facilities, fewer routes and fewer people in our organization as we go forward, right? That's the structural cost that has inherent inefficiency in it as we move to the supply chain that we're going to have on a go-forward basis in the future.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now hear from Jon Feeney with Janney. [Janney Montgomery Scott]
componenttext: We'll now hear from Jon Feeney with Janney. [Janney Montgomery Scott]

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gregg, I wanted to just go out with a little bit more specificity, something a couple of people have asked about, which is, when are some of these competitors going to be forced to get more rational? When I compare this quarter in terms of operating profi
componenttext: Gregg, I wanted to just go out with a little bit more specificity, something a couple of people have asked about, which is, when are some of these competitors going to be forced to get more rational? When I compare this quarter in terms of operating profit per gallon to the worst other one I've seen on record, which would have Q2 '07. Other than Q1 this year, Q2 '07 worked about, by my estimates of what you've told us, like 4% gallon growth, whatever, we're about 32% below in profit per gallon for you. If you take effect to the $36 million in quarterly cost savings you'd achieved as of last September, with the 145 [ph] number you told us. So when I think about that and then I think about the branded to private label mix that you suffered, it has to be much worse at these other regionals, because they're going to do a lot less private label business than you are, so they're going to feel worse trade-down, if you will, whatever you want to call it, that impact of going from branded to private label profits. What's the number? Where is it? These guys are half due, are not making a return on their assets, and have you seen any -- I mean, forget about what you're hearing in the marketplace, has anybody filed? Has anybody liquidated? Is anybody getting out of the business that you've heard of in the industry?

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the one thing -- I think you've characterized the factors that would argue for some stabilization of processor pricing in the marketplace. I think you have to look at the flip-side of the total profit pool as you look between retailers and process
componenttext: I think the one thing -- I think you've characterized the factors that would argue for some stabilization of processor pricing in the marketplace. I think you have to look at the flip-side of the total profit pool as you look between retailers and processors. And that is the size of the investment that retailers have made in this industry is the encountering factor to keeping processors aggressive, right? Retailers have made significant investments over the last 12-plus months in this business, and they're trying to recover some of that investment from processors. Processors are sitting with stranded fixed costs, so they're doing whatever they can do to hold onto their volumes. So they're being very aggressive from a price standpoint in order to avoid further deleverage. So I think, as Gregg commented, processors are not out trying to take other processors volumes. They're just trying to hold onto their own volume with retailers trying to extract concessions from the processor community. So that's the countering force in the overall profitability drain in the processor industry. Retailers are still trying to recover some profit pool. I think when you start seeing that abate, when their investments starts becoming less, then you'll see a little of the pressure taken off processors. And I think you'll see margins start to stabilize on the processor side of the business.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Jonathan, to your, “When does the industry tip and have to shed capacity?” This last year feels like about 10 years to me, and I'm sure it does to you guys that follow the industry. But I would remind you that one year ago on our call, we were tal
componenttext: And Jonathan, to your, “When does the industry tip and have to shed capacity?” This last year feels like about 10 years to me, and I'm sure it does to you guys that follow the industry. But I would remind you that one year ago on our call, we were talking about the third quarter of what was going to be our most profitable year ever. And that is true for everybody in the industry, right? We just made a historically anomalously high amount of money. And so everybody came into this with pretty full provisions. And people are going to have to believe that this is the new normal, which I think you're hearing us say, we think it is, and are going to have to experience it for a while before they look for a different course of action. The industry has always gone through ups and downs, and the downs always been followed within relatively short order by ups, usually driven by the commodity cycle. And I'm not sure everybody sees it the same way we do. In terms of stressed consumers, much more aggressive retailers and more well-informed and educated retailers and pressure of a perceives [ph] as the marketplace has changed as fundamentally as we believe it has changed. So until everybody comes to that conclusion and they start running out of this money they husbanded, I'm not sure that the world changes a lot. I think it's going to be a while.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And it sounds to me, to summarize what you inject, you have a -- it's the two large retailers that are not significant customers of yours, but it seemed to be what changed at the margin in the industry, their view of profits relative to other benefits the
componenttext: And it sounds to me, to summarize what you inject, you have a -- it's the two large retailers that are not significant customers of yours, but it seemed to be what changed at the margin in the industry, their view of profits relative to other benefits they might get from driving milk volume.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know if I could fairly characterize it that way. What I do really believe, though, is that if they knew now what they knew then, they probably would not have gone down this path. Because whatever benefit they got from cheap milk prices -- I mean,
componenttext: I don't know if I could fairly characterize it that way. What I do really believe, though, is that if they knew now what they knew then, they probably would not have gone down this path. Because whatever benefit they got from cheap milk prices -- I mean, look at it, we got historically cheap margin over milk, and volumes in the grocery segment are down 4%. I mean, that's just not a winning strategy at retail. But it's very hard to walk back from that in this kind of economy.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jack, are you at liberty to say where you're going and when you will be able to [indiscernible] if you can?
componenttext: Jack, are you at liberty to say where you're going and when you will be able to [indiscernible] if you can?

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: It will be announced in the coming weeks.
componenttext: It will be announced in the coming weeks.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, we have time for one more question, and we'll take that from John Baumgartner from Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, we have time for one more question, and we'll take that from John Baumgartner from Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gregg, shifting to WhiteWave here, specifically at Horizon, any view there on organic milk supplies in 2011 and where your sourcing cost might go?
componenttext: Gregg, shifting to WhiteWave here, specifically at Horizon, any view there on organic milk supplies in 2011 and where your sourcing cost might go?

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we've seen this demand volume in the category pickup, it obviously starts to put a little bit of pressure back on the supply end of the business. So you're going to see some pressure on farm, price to farmers, and Gregg already alluded to fact tha
componenttext: Yes. As we've seen this demand volume in the category pickup, it obviously starts to put a little bit of pressure back on the supply end of the business. So you're going to see some pressure on farm, price to farmers, and Gregg already alluded to fact that input cost are going to start going up. So I think you're going to see a little pressure on pay price to farmers as we go forward right now. It doesn't feel like there is a lack of supply. I don't think we're going to be supply constrained next year. I think it's going to tighten up. And I think you're going to see some cost pressure on pay price to farmers. But I don't think we're going to be in a situation where we get upside down between demand and supply.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I guess, thinking conventional milk, and I guess just reconciling some of the USDA fluid milk category of volume and kind of the softness there, with some of the raw milk production numbers coming out. What's the difference there? I mean, are we
componenttext: And then I guess, thinking conventional milk, and I guess just reconciling some of the USDA fluid milk category of volume and kind of the softness there, with some of the raw milk production numbers coming out. What's the difference there? I mean, are we seeing a big mix shift as far as utilization goes into finished dairy products?

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, the reality is and has been for a long time that only about 30% of milk production in the U.S. goes to drinking milk. The other 2/3 go into cheese and butter and powder and ingredients and exports. So it's probably a commonly held misperception
componenttext: Yes, John, the reality is and has been for a long time that only about 30% of milk production in the U.S. goes to drinking milk. The other 2/3 go into cheese and butter and powder and ingredients and exports. So it's probably a commonly held misperception that drinking milk drives the category. It really doesn't.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I guess, just finally, just following up on Eric's question, can you talk a little bit about your thoughts on the Ice Cream business as a strategic component going forward. I'm just kind of thinking about, as you focus on the second phase of cost
componenttext: And then I guess, just finally, just following up on Eric's question, can you talk a little bit about your thoughts on the Ice Cream business as a strategic component going forward. I'm just kind of thinking about, as you focus on the second phase of cost initiatives here, might the Ice Cream business be a little bit less essential going forward, given your competitive position there?

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Ice Cream business is a business that we're in primarily because we bought fluid milk businesses that were in it. So we never set out to build a strategic position in ice cream. On the other hand, it's become a $900 million business for us, and so we
componenttext:
The Ice Cream business is a business that we're in primarily because we bought fluid milk businesses that were in it. So we never set out to build a strategic position in ice cream. On the other hand, it's become a $900 million business for us, and so we have to think about it strategically. And it's a business that has produced, over time, a healthy profitability for us. We have some very good regionally branded positions in the business. But I think it's a fair point to say that we have to sort out over time where we're going with Ice Cream. Unlike WhiteWave, however, Ice Cream is pretty embedded in our fluid dairy business today. So the level of complexity in changing direction there is quite high.  
Thank you all for joining us on the call this morning. We look forward to talking to you in February when we report our full year results. And in the meantime, hope to see and have conversations with many of you and your clients over the coming weeks and months. Thank you.

headline: Dean Foods Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude our conference for today. We thank you for participation.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude our conference for today. We thank you for participation.
